lines.text: I'm going to be blunt, and make some very cutting remarks.
To be sure, sir, that's a contradiction in terms, but then English is a very curious language!
If you interrupt me once more, Mr....?
Marjoribanks, sir.
You interrupt me once more, mate, and you'll hear some really curious language!
not my favourite occupation.
Nor mine.
It's going to be from now on.
Charming.
Health Report, Dock Report, Crew Report, Food Report, Log Report, Sports Report, Diesel Oil and Fuel Report.

]
And a partridge in a pear tree!
[Haines, while looking for the kitchen, enters a small cabin]
Well, this isn't the kitchen!
I should say not. It's the Captain's day cabin.

]
Cosy, very cosy. I don't suppose you know where the kitchen is?
Sorry, chum, I'm a stranger round here myself.
Another new face? You'll cop the lot!
[Haines exits]
Flo! Ebb a bit.
You're overwrought!
I'm underprivileged!
I always find the first few days make me feel quite drowsy.
Shut your port-hole.
Begging your pardon, sir, one must have fresh...
...and your cake-hole.
Gentlemen, have I your agreement for a policy of unremitting quasi-teutonic organisational protectionism?
Every time I look at you I hear music.
Every time I look at you I think of music.
You do?
Colonel Bogey. Excuse me.
[Exits]

[Haines, having come to sick bay for a sea-sickness cure, refuses to have an injection in his arm]
I can't bear to see the needle going in, you see.
Well, in that case there's only one other place for it to go. Drop 'em!
I'm not holding them, whatever they are!
I gather the Doctor means your trousers.
Oh. What!
[Captain Crowther enters his cabin, and finds Tom Tree putting clothes in the drawers]
Don't tell me. You're my new steward. Lovall has broken his leg. You've only done three trips, all from Tower Bridge to Margate.
That's right, sir. How can you tell?
I'm psychic!
[Glances at his list]
Tom Tree.
That's right, sir. Branches everywhere!
Love, hey?
How did you know?
That's why I drink. To forget her.
Forget who?
Blessed if I can remember.

[With a very bad Spanish accent]
Ole, señor!
Oh, hello Binn.
No, señor. I am the famous Torero from Madrid.
You look exactly like our medical officer, Dr Binn.
No, Señor. This afternoon I fight 15 bulls.
That's an awful lot of bull.
Well, my father he breeds the famous fighting bulls, you know. Every year, 50,000 bulls he sends off by ship to South America.
50,000 bulls?
Si, si. Also every year, 20,000 more he ships off to France.
That's 70,000 bulls.
Si, si. One of the biggest bullshippers in the business.

[Walking into bar]
Who are you?
Me, sir? Turner, sir.
Turner?
Turner, sir.
What are you doin' 'ere?
Head barman, sir.
You can't be head barman. Angus is my head barman.

[Smiling]
Not anymore, sir.
Not any more? They can't do this to me! Changing a barman? It's like ripping out the engine!
